bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, July 10, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Ireland photographs from Washington and a copy of his speech at the Cornwell painting unveiling. He informs Ireland of Kissinger's stroke and Blossom Reed's heart attack.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, July 10, 1941
div1.p:
I am belatedly sending you the snapshots I took in Washington.
I am very glad to have them as a souvenir of what was to me a most delight-
ful meeting. I am enclosing also a copy of my Cleveland talk in case you
care to have it. I have sent one to Generals Kean and Truby and to Miss
Agramonte and Mr. Moran.

I suppose you heard of the sorrowful aftermath of our delightful
Cleveland affair. Just thirty-six hours later Kissinger had a severe and
almost fatal storke. He wasn't expected to recover at all, but he (unfor-
tunately) still lingers, completely paralyzed on his right side with his
speech (and also his vision) notably impaired. Poor Mrs. Kissinger is
desperate and broken-hearted. I am trying to make discreet inquiries to
see if anything can be done to lighten their trouble. Perhaps he could
be transferred to a veterans' hospital or even to Walter Reed if or when
he became movable.

Just this week a friend of Mrs. Blossom Reed wrote me that last
week Mrs. Blossom had suffered a “severe heart attack” and “might be con-
fined to bed for months.” Her mother has not been told the cause of her
disability and is not to know it for fear of the consequences. I feel
so sorry about all this. But how nice that she and Kissinger had the
real pleasure of the Cleveland affair.

I am still corresponding with those in charge of the map division
in Washington and have just heard the good news from the chief clerk of
the Surgeon General's office that the correspondence between Sternberg
and the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board has been unearthed and will be avail-
able for me to study at Fort Myer, whenever I can get there. I do hope
to go again to Washington this fall.

Permit me to say again what an Honor and privilege it was for
me to meet you and Mrs. Ireland.
